results.title: The First moving picture show
results.brief_description: A short claymation piece giving a unique perspective on early cinema. Plasticine models and simple drawings are combined with limited dialogue to show how pictures were made to move.

results.title: The First motion picture show
results.brief_description: Excellent combination of artwork, old still photos, and animation illustrates the successive stages leading to the first successful public motion-picture demonstration in 1880. Traces the technological development of the three essential components of the motion picture: projection, animation and photography.

results.title: The First mile up
results.brief_description: A film on air pollution, with surprising disclosures of what the seemingly empty air around us holds. The film noses around the atmosphere that encloses our Earth - the comparatively thin envelope of air on which all life depends. The problem is discussed by engineers, health authorities and scientists, including Nobel-prize-winning chemist Dr. Linus Pauling.

results.title: The First many-celled animals: sponges
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Walker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Demonstrates that the sponge represents one development of multicellularity in animals. Shows life processes and the adaptation of sponges to their environment. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The first home console
results.brief_description: In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

constellations_primary.name: The first home console and the art of ping pong
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of tennis and ping pong throughout the moving image.

results.description:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

Originally called the ‘TV Game Unit #7’, Baer’s prototype became better known as the Brown Box because of its faux wood-grain vinyl. It ran multiple programs and games – including ping-pong, checkers and four different sports games – which were controlled by flipping the switches on the front of the unit.

The Magnavox Odyssey was released in 1972. Players controlled two dots while the console controlled another that darted around the screen and could be returned like the ball in pong. Though the basic gameplay was the same, people could put graphic overlays over their TV to create different game experiences, like skiing and football.
description_for_label:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

Originally called the ‘TV Game Unit #7’, Baer’s prototype became better known as the Brown Box because of its faux wood-grain vinyl. It ran multiple programs and games – including ping-pong, checkers and four different sports games – which were controlled by flipping the switches on the front of the unit.

The Magnavox Odyssey was released in 1972. Players controlled two dots while the console controlled another that darted around the screen and could be returned like the ball in pong. Though the basic gameplay was the same, people could put graphic overlays over their TV to create different game experiences, like skiing and football.

results.title: The First forests
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Life on Earth”.
Part 3 of a series which traces the dramatic history of life on earth from its beginnings about 3,500 million years ago to the final emergence of man. In this episode David Attenborough discusses the evolution of plants from the first algae and moss-like plants that crept onto the land from the waters edge to the giant trees of todays forests, showing how they solved the two major problems of support and reproduction in the absence of water. The arrival of plants on land made it possible for animal life to live there as well and the evolution of the first plants and animals is inextricably linked. Also examines how plants grew taller, seeking light and how insects developed wings to reach their food sources. Microphotography is used to reveal unsuspected details of mosses, liverworts, ferns, cycads and conifers.

results.title: The First five minutes
results.brief_description: Illustrates the fact that the first five minutes are the most important in fighting fires. Shows the best methods to be used in preventing and extinguishing fires by brigades organised in industries as well as municipal brigades.

results.title: The First fifty years: Kenya and Tanganyika
results.creator_credit: Mercury Film Productions and Sylvia Story
results.brief_description: The development of the grain milling industry in Kenya and Tanganyika. The major part of the film deals with the work of UNGA, a large scale wheat growing and marketing organisation in Kenya, with other sequences giving a general picture of progress in the agricultural industry, underlining the contribution of modern plant, qualified technicians, research and advisory services.

results.title: The First few months
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
Parents are likely to encounter some problems during the first few months after the birth of their child. These problems include meeting the needs of demanding babies, coping with an unsettled baby, maintaining support when tired and irritable, and simply finding some peace and quiet. Relaxation techniques are discussed, ways to handle babies are demonstrated and preparations for “baby’s” first venture “outside” by car, travel, etc are also discussed.

results.title: The First essential skills
results.creator_credit: United Nautical Publishers, Richard Creagh-Osborne and Joachim Schult
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Sailing”.
One of a course of three films of instruction in sailing a small light dinghy (420 class). Intended for schools, sailing schools and clubs. Animation by Peter Milne.
